Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
COASSTal Communities of Science is a citizen-science project whose goal is to increase the scientific and educational reach of a highly successful, action-oriented and rigorous citizen science program - the Coastal Observation And Seabird Survey Team (COASST), by adding a new data module on marine debris that will feature innovative technological approaches including mobile apps and web-based crowdsourcing. The marine debris module will complement an existing module on beached birds, allowing COASST to more completely assess coastal environmental health. For instance, marine debris data, focused particularly on issues of invasive species, harm to wildlife, and debris sourcing, will be immediately useful in marine science and resource management. Once designed and vetted by professional scientists and science educators, the new module will be implemented by citizen scientists in over 100 in-community trainings conducted throughout the COASST geographic range, from northern California to the coast of Alaska, including remote coastal communities with limited access to scientific information. Over 1,000 new participants will join the program, bringing the total number of active volunteers to 2,000 within the 4 years of the project.

A complementary social science research component will advance the field of informal STEM learning by focusing on the factors facilitating recruitment and especially retention in citizen science projects, using COASST as a model. The current models of science learning in informal contexts will be extended by bringing them together with conceptual approaches to the development of interest, communities of practice, and activity theory. Research will specifically focus on differences in individual motivation to join COASST; follow participants as they enter the program and eventually become central members of the COASST community of practice; and assess the degree to which individual, programmatic and socio-cultural factors contribute to participant retention. A linked independent evaluation will assess the depth of learning individuals experience as a function the training and materials they receive, and amount and type of data they collect. Both research and evaluation components will utilize pre/post surveys, interviews, and longitudinal journaling.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Coastal Observation and Seabird Survey Team (COASST) is a citizen science program housed at the University of Washington in Seattle, focused on the environment of the northeast Pacific. Coastal community members serve as essential scientific partners, collecting high-quality data on local beaches from northern California to Alaska.

COASST began 20 years ago with a survey program documenting patterns of mortality with beached seabirds, but in the last seven years the National Science Foundation has supported the development and implementation phases of a new survey module to collect data on the distribution and impact of marine debris. With iterative input from pilot participants, COASST staff created and tested a survey protocol and training format for marine debris surveyors.  A second protocol, for beached bird data collection in remote Alaskan coastal communities, was also developed and implemented during the grant period.

An advisory board and external evaluator reviewed COASST's new marine debris module at each stage of development, and a series of surveys and journaling prompts were distributed to training participants in order to measure the learning impact in the COASST training program. COASST participants demonstrated statistically significant gains in content and skills learning after attending expert-led training in both modules. Survey responses showed that the practice of surveying beaches did not reinforce all concepts taught in the training modules.

Over the course of this grant 37 marine debris and 125 beached bird training events took place, connecting 1500 local community members to an expanded involvement in science and launching an entirely new data collection module for COASST. Retention of new participants exceeded 44% for the new debris module, and 59% for the beached bird module.  Within the marine debris program over 1,800 surveys were performed and over 27,000 items of marine debris were found, characterized and entered into the database. The protocol was accepted by both NOAA and EPA.

An undergraduate internship program supported this effort, with more than 100 students involved in outreach, science communication, and data coordination. COASST staff and students presented research findings to public and professional audiences at more than 150 events. In addition to a summative evaluation report, 16 papers were published in peer-reviewed journals: 8 involving COASST citizen science data, and 8 focused on the social science of citizen science, including recruitment, retention, identity and science learning.  Two postdoctoral fellows were supported, each of which authored multiple peer-reviewed papers.  COASST received a Partner of the Year award from the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service for work with coastal Alaskan communities.
